description.plain:
Sade (pronounced “shah-day”) is a Grammy Award-winning English band formed in London in 1982. The group is named after lead singer Sade Adu, who is also a songwriter and producer for the group, which also includes Stuart Matthewman, Paul S. Denman, and Andrew Hale as the multi-instrumentalist backing band. Their musical style ties together multiple genres, from funk to smooth jazzy quiet storm R&B/soul—a style labeled as sophisti-pop.

Sade released their multi-platinum debut album Diamond Life in 1984, which featured the hit singles “Your Love is King”, “Hang On To Your Love”, and “Smooth Operator”. They followed that album with Promise the following year, which featured the hit singles “Is It a Crime”, “Never as Good as the First Time”, and “The Sweetest Taboo”. Promise peaked at #1 on the US Billboard 200 chart and sold millions of copies worldwide. The group also won the Best New Artist Grammy Award in 1986 for the success of their first two albums.

Their multi-platinum streak continued with their third album Stronger Than Pride (1988)—featuring the hit singles “Paradise”, “Nothing Can Come Between Us”, “Love is Stronger Than Pride”, and “Turn My Back On You”—as well as their fourth album Love Deluxe (1992), which featured the hit singles “Kiss of Life”, “Cherish the Day”, and “No Ordinary Love”, which won a Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals.

After an 8-year hiatus, Sade picked up right where they left off with the release of their fifth album, Lovers Rock, on November 13, 2000. The album won a Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album, as their smooth sound was featured on the album’s singles, “By Your Side” and “King of Sorrow”. The group took another lengthy break before releasing their sixth album, Soldier of Love in 2010. The title track won a Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals, while the album peaked at #1 in multiple countries and was another multi-platinum success like all of their previous albums.

In 2018, the group contributed the song “Flower of the Universe” to the soundtrack of A Wrinkle in Time and “The Big Unknown” to the Widows soundtrack.

songs.title: By Your Side

description.plain:
“By Your Side,” released January 12, 2001, is the lead single from Sade’s fifth album Lovers Rock, and the first new music from the band since 1993’s “Please Send Me Someone To Love” appeared on the soundtrack of the Tom Hanks film Philadelphia.

In the lyrics of the song about loyalty in love (whether romantic or platonic), Sade expresses the strength and significance of a lover/friend, pledging not to let them feel alone or suffer in isolation.

The brightly colored music video was directed by longtime collaborator Sophie Muller who said this of the video clip:

It is like a metaphor of life. Because she has been away, yet has this amazing life and has come back to delivered this album. That was meant to be a metaphor, like the flower like she dropped by the roadside saying, ‘Here is my album.’ Then she made like she has gone through this strange journey, which is her life, but it is totally made into a beautiful, mysterious dream. The song was very uplifting in that way.

songs.title: Smooth Operator

description.plain:
“Smooth Operator” was the third single from Sade’s blockbuster debut album Diamond Life, which takes its title from the first line of this song. The single reached #5 on the US Billboard 100 charts, and #19 on the UK Singles Chart.

The song is about a dominant, alpha-male lover who is no good for her, but still irresistible. The song’s lyrics and title would be referenced regularly by hip-hop artists, including Rakim, Big Daddy Kane, and Snoop Dogg.

Though the singles for the song list Sade Adu, Stuart Matthewman and Raymond St. John as the writers, PRS credits only list Sade and Raymond St. John. Supposedly, the two wrote the song in 1982 with members of Sade’s previous band, Pride. They didn’t record it then because St. John left Pride shortly after Sade joined.

songs.title: No Ordinary Love

description.plain:
“No Ordinary Love” was featured in the 1993 Robert Redford film “Indecent Proposal.”

The song peaked at #14 on the U.K. Singles chart, #28 on the Billboard Hot 100, #14 on Billboard’s Adult Contemporary chart and #9 on Billboard’s R&B chart, staying on the chart for 20 weeks in 1993.

It won Sade a Grammy Award for “Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals.”

songs.title: The Sweetest Taboo

description.plain: The “Sweetest Taboo” is the height of sexual pleasure, and Sade sings lovingly about a man who gets her there in this song. The line “There’s a quiet storm” is a reference to the Quiet Storm radio format, which is filled with baby-making music like this song. The song is the lead single from Sade’s 2nd LP Promise.

songs.title: Cherish the Day

In the U.S., the song peaked at #16 on Billboard’s Bubbling Under Hot 100 Singles chart, #23 on Billboard’s Hot Dance Music\Maxi-Singles Sales chart and #45 on Billboard’s R&B chart, staying on the chart for 17 weeks.

songs.full_title: Your Love Is King by Sade
songs.title: Your Love Is King

description.plain:
As an artist who sings a lot about love (i.e. Hang on to Your Love, No Ordinary Love, Lover’s Pride) it is easy to rank “Your Love is King” as yet another installment in Sade’s praise for love as romantic affection, tenderness and the spiritual connection that bind two people.

However, do not be fooled!  This song is also and, I would say, primarily about a woman who is experiencing orgasm because her lover is performing oral sex on her.  With her sultry voice to boot, this is Sade at her sensual best…

(By the way, the version is not the original, but at least it’s still with Sade’s voice)
Start song at 1:45

songs.full_title: The Moon and the Sky by Sade
songs.title: The Moon and the Sky

description.plain:
“The Moon and The Sky” is a track from Sade’s 2010 album Soldier of Love. Though the track wasn’t released as a single, the compilation album The Ultimate Collection was issued the following year with a “The Moon and the Sky” remix featuring Jay Z.

An NPR interview lauded the song as a return to form for Sade after their 10 year absence from the music industry:

Adu’s voice does much of the work here — she has a distinct coolness to her timbre, a penchant for elongating her vowels and an accented inflection that have become her signatures over the years, whether in the new “The Moon and the Sky” or in 1984’s “Smooth Operator.”

songs.title: Soldier of Love

description.plain:
“Soldier of Love” was the lead single from Sade’s 2010 album Soldier of Love, the group’s first since Lovers Rock in 2000.

Released in December 2009, the military-themed rhythmic track about resilience in love expectedly shot to #1 on the Billboard Adult R&B charts. Its cinematic music video was directed by longtime collaborator Sophie Muller, with choreography by the legendary Fatima Robinson.

In February 2011, “Soldier of Love” won the Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals.

songs.title: Like a Tattoo

description.plain:
The final night of Sade’s 1993 Love Deluxe World Tour, Sade explained to her audience that “Like A Tattoo” was a true story based on the accounts of a stranger Sade met years ago on an evening at a New York City bar:

A long time ago, I met a man in a bar in New York. He told me his story. This is his song. It’s about war and what he had to go through.

The song’s grave tone reflects his guilt and shame  over committing a war crime. Over the course of the song, we learn that he shot and killed a man who had his hands up in surrender—an act that may have also been witnessed by a significant woman in the victim’s life. But despite the soldier’s egregious act, the intensity of his regret is only possible because of the empathy present in his heart; his love for humanity.

songs.title: Babyfather

description.plain:
“Babyfather” is the second single off Sade’s sixth studio album Soldier Of Love. It was sent to radio airplay on April 20th, 2010.

“Babyfather” is a song dedicated to Sade Adu’s daughter, Ila. It was inspired by the singer’s relationship with her daughter’s father and her current partner.



In 1995, Adu had a brief relationship with Jamaican music producer Bob Morgan and gave birth to their daughter Ila. However, soon after, the couple separated. The singer has since been in a long-term relationship with Ian Watts whom she considers to be Ila’s dad.

Ila Adu actually appears as a background vocalist on the song’s credits.

A music video for “Babyfather”, directed by Sade’s long-time collaborator Sophie Muller, was released through Vevo on May 4, 2010.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?list=SRsade%20baby%20father&v=XoHWjG6LUsA

The song was nominated in the Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal category at the 53rd Grammy Awards.

songs.title: Paradise

description.plain:
“Paradise” is considered one of Sade’s signature songs.

It became a number-one R&B hit for the band, topping Billboard’s R&B chart for a week in July of 1988, making it their only U.S. number-one R&B hit to date.

It also peaked at #16 on the Billboard Hot 100 and #29 on the U.K. Singles chart.

songs.title: King of Sorrow

description.plain:
Sade is carrying a heavy heart after a breakdown in her relationship. It appears there is no solutions to their issues as she wallows in grief, even if the dj is playing different songs in a setlist, they all sound the same to her through this portion of emotions.

Leaving the situation is an option in spite of what the future may hold but ultimately this is a internal journey to persevere through the “private war”.

songs.title: Tar Baby

description.plain:
The “Tar-Baby” is an integral part of one of Joel Harris' well known tales of “Uncle Remus,” specifically in http://xroads.virginia.edu/~ug97/remus/tar-baby.html .

In the tale, the character of Br'er Rabbit, a cunning anthropomorphic rabbit, is walking along a path when he sees a figure made of tar, constructed by Br'er Fox. When the tar figure doesn’t respond to his greeting, Br'er Rabbit strikes the tar figure with his hand, which results in him getting stuck in it. Repeated attempts at striking the tar figure ultimately results in Br'er Rabbit being completely stuck within in, and Br'er Fox capturing him.

A “Tar Baby” now refers to a paradoxical situation, and one which should’ve been avoided in the first place.

Sade uses this colloquial sentiment to describe the unwanted pregnancy of a mother’s youthful daughter.

Upon initial arrival and through its youth, the baby is treated as a nuisance and with disdain, considering its inadvertent appearance imposed unavoidable setbacks onto its parent’s lives.

As the song winds down, however, the mother and daughter gaze upon the child with an ounce of sympathy and love; the baby did not ask to be born, and shouldn’t be treated perfunctorily and with disrespect.

songs.title: Maureen

description.plain:
“Maureen” is the uptempo closing track of Sade’s Promise album. Sade Adu told the New York Times about the song on November 27, 1985:

“‘Maureen’ is personally my favorite song on the album, because it’s about a friend who died five years ago,” she continued. “I didn’t want it to be sad or self-indulgent but to represent the joy and good times we had together. I think of it as a happy tribute. The song came almost like magic. It was written in two hours.”

The song’s opening percussion was later sampled into Jus Jam’s “Springtime” in 2018.

songs.title: Fear

description.plain:
This song narrates the anxious experience of a woman waiting for her lover to come back home. However, it all has a different meaning since her lover is, apparently, a matador (“killer”), a bullfighter, which is a very dangerous profession; she fears for his life every day.



The song references bullfighting in numerous ways: with the color red, which is the color of the flags that are waved in front of the bulls (because it supposedly “angers” them); and the Spanish verses, that allude to this activity’s country of origin, Spain.

songs.full_title: You're Not the Man by Sade
songs.title: You’re Not the Man

description.plain: This song is about Sade letting a guy he is not who she thought was or at least expected. Most females can relate to this after being let down in the end of a relationship or cheated on in the end, this song is perfect for situations like that. Too bad this masterpiece didn’t get much attentions as the other singles and hits on this album.
